embeds.title: Headbutt
embeds.description:
Common Attack / 1 :energy_champ: / The Champ / Downfall

Deal 9 (12) damage.
Put a card from your discard pile on top of your draw pile.

messages.content: the less card draw a character has, the more valuable card manipulation is

kinda mid, why play a balanced attack when you have broken ones? This is mostly used for exclusively its secondary effect and its fine when you use it for that purpose; I don't find myself wanting a headbutt in my deck that often though.
this feels out of place with champ, not only is it a reskin but it also doesn't interact with any of your mechanics.
it mostly interacts with <Enraged Bash>

embeds.title: Enraged Bash
embeds.description:
Uncommon Attack / 1 :energy_champ: / The Champ / Downfall

Deal 7 (10) damage.
Berserker **Combo:** This card hits an additional time this combat.

messages.content:
It's deck manipulation, it doesn't need to interact with character's mechanics to justify its existence, as its main job is providing consistency when it comes to card draw, or setting up powerful card combos.
 That said it kinda doesn't really work well due to the fact that Champ's usually strategy revolves around stacking **Vigor**, which doesn't like you playing Attacks, but it is a problem that will be solved at some point, when I figure out better effects for **Stances** that is.
do you know what the design philosophy behind champ was?
was it just another stance character with some skill triggers?
like current champ, or fatigue champ?
or was there something deeper they were trying to achieve
any

Well for starters one of his moves is literally called **Defensive Stance**, so we needed to make him a Stance character, next point was trying to be different than Watcher, and finally general fencing terms, for a character that barely worked, then every patch after his release was trying to fix the character slowly powercreaping his card pool and replacing what didn't work, finally add a small amount of trying to simplify the character and fix his issues and you have his current form, at this point I think that the only reasonable way to fix the character's issues is to basically redesign him from scratch, while taking into account highs and lows of the previous ideas.
from this it sounds like the design process ended up feeling forced rather than having something really coherent to work with
which honestly makes sense, if true
also it's ironic
that one of the few deliberate intents of designing Champ was to make him different from watcher
not sure how well that turned out

That is sadly how design of some of the Villains goes, as all we have is 1 Boss fight and maybe few Relics and we have to make a character from that, which is surprisingly limiting as we want to emulate how playing a character would feel, while also having a lot of potential for different builds.
 That said my focus at the moment is improving (and simplifying certain aspects of) already existing characters.
yeah, gotta focus on the small fixable stuff first
As there is no point in having 11 characters when half of them don't have enough build options to feel interesting for more than 3 runs.
yes
i think i have some insight on the champ situation that could help
I am listening, well reading in this case.
Evab about to pull out an entire document

So, everyone thinks of Watcher as The Stance Character, but upon taking a closer look at her cards (to learn how to make a character), I realized that her overarching theme goes beyond just Stances - it's Timing. While Stances are probably the most prevalent mechanic, especially with double damage attached to Wrath, Timing manifests itself in almost all of her mechanics.

You want to control your timing of when you enter Wrath so you don't take damage, and to a lesser extent, time Calm entry to when you can afford those cards, in order to set up Energy for later. There are cards like Sash Whip and Follow Up that require being played after a certain type of card, and Halt which likes being played in a certain stance. Retain also fits this, as keeping cards for future turns enables them to be timed to when you want to use them, Miracles especially.

So her overall playstyle revolves around something deeper than just stances, and everything revolves around that central theme. What I've noticed Champ has in his current kit is Damage Combos. Although he is broken for it, people really enjoy building up Vigor and then dumping it for huge damage in another attack. I think you can revolve around this idea - the Skill Bonus mechanic really leans into this idea already. Even though you're forced into stances, if you were to figure out stances that deal damage in different ways but also support each other's damage types, stances could be combo'd into each other for really interesting damage combos.
I am already thinking about my observations, so I will be ready to quickly contrast them with what Evab will say.
basically, stances are more than stances.

Yeah, timing and card order on Watcher is pretty important. Also Stances incentivise quickly switching into **Wrath** gaining as much value as possible and existing it at the end of the turn, while Calm exists as just as slightly better alternative than exiting to neutral, ironically devs had identical idea for initial Champ build, enter at the start of the turn, use **Techniques** and/or **Combos**, and end with a **Finisher**, but it didn't really work due to how many different types of cards you had to draw, and how many cards had only one role, which ment that there wasn't a lot of value on relying on draw for every turn, and just focusing on **Combo**/**Technique** was much better and more consistent (in result turning third of a card pool into dead cards), if you excluded the terrible card pool that was consumed by each card being reprinted 3 times (1 variant for each Stance) for some reason, and they barely provided anything outside of character mechanics so it was pretty hard to get usual damage/Block/draw effects.
 I went on a bit of a tangent on how bad original Champ design was, but that is kinda expected when it comes to discussing character mechanics.
one more thing i want to say about champ is that i was very disappointed that the character didn't lean into champ's cockiness
i thought we were going to get a character whose mechanics were designed around that and i thought that'd be a really funny design
instead we have a serious fighter with Taunt and Vicious Mockery
can't forget about <Face Slap>

embeds.title: Face Slap
embeds.description:
Uncommon Attack / 1 :energy_champ: / The Champ / Downfall

Deal 8 (10) damage.
Berserker **Combo:** Apply 2 (3) **Vulnerable** :p_vulnerable:.

messages.content:
It is kinda hard to design as it either means debuffing yourself or buffing enemies, both of which are hard to well without just feeling extremely counterintuitive to play.
> There is also an option involving **Status** cards, but that is already occupied pretty well by Ironclad and Auto, and we don't need another character that focuses on that.
Btw I want to add a potential debuff focused build, as well as make discard more common as a downside (as well as add some stuff that rewards discarding), so that part of a character might be found there.
the central theme is the most important thing to design around, whatever it ends up being
Yeah, I need something to focus on, as otherwise character has pretty high chance of doing everything and simultaneously achieving nothing.

Things that I found out by letting the ideas for the character spin in my head for a while:
-Current Combo mechanic and its variations are pretty bad for basing majority of the card pool around, as it often leads to catch 22 situations when picking the cards during the run, no matter how good the synergy between different **Stances** might be.
-Half of the Attack cards I design end up feeling like the should be **Finishers**, so I probably should do something about it like completely changing how mechanics work to exclude that line of text that would appear nearly everywhere.
I think it makes sense to eliminate the Combo keyword, I always felt it was restricting and not enabling
also I think you could very easily fix a big problem with finishers by making them playable without a stance
they're similarly too restricting and have issues even if you balance their density well in your deck
they should be less of a card to trigger a bonus and more of a card that really likes being played after setting them up with other cards
like how execute likes being played after gaining vigor
but <moment of truth>?

embeds.title: Moment of Truth
embeds.description:
Uncommon Skill / 0 :energy_champ: / The Champ / Downfall

**Retain**.
Draw 1 (2) card (cards).
:finisher:   **Finisher**

messages.content: yeah, it draws a card ._.
ok moment of truth has issues
wowee
I know that's like saying "water is wet"

Also **Counter** is kinda boring and **Vigor** creates very repetitive and passive playstyle, which means that both mechanics should be less present on a character, preferably reduced to something like 1 card that you build around.
At this point it is just glorified "Exit your Stance" might as replace the keyword with something more interesting and redesign the **Stances** to reflect that.
wouldn't be opposed to that. it's already glorified "exit your stance" just with "unplayable sometimes" attached

Some of my current ideas that may or may not work:
-Changing **Combo** to:
> **Combo X**
> If your last card played this combat was X, trigger the following effect.
 I think that it is a nice starting point when it comes to translating the card pool, as most of current **Combo** cards would work well with if your last card was an Attack or Skill, for **Berserker** and **Defensive Stance** respectfully, and the keyword leaves a lot of flexibility when it comes to more specific requirements.
 
-**Finishers** just changing the current **Finisher** cards to use:
> **Technique X**
> If you have enough **Courage** spend that amount to trigger following effect, otherwise gain 1 **Courage**.
> > Keyword is currently WIP.
> > Courage normally doesn't do anything it is just a resource for strong cards.
Just something very easy when it comes to mechanics, but it might be fun to play with, and build around trying to exploit the mechanic.

And finally **Defensive Stance**:
> Whenever you play a card gain 2 **Block**.
> On exit, ALL enemies take damage equal to your **Block**.
I still have to figure out other **Stances**, but I like this effect, and it should be somewhat balanced with cards that exit your **Stance** being mostly stance entries.

Also I would like to replace **Vigor** with temp **Strength** and just cut **Counter**.

Also an idea for rework of **Vicious Mockery**
> Uncommon Power
> At the end of your turn, every enemy takes ? damage per every debuff they have.
Seems that the nuclear button has been pressed
it is a good time to press it though
defensive stance = 2x after image
champ doesn't have shivs but still
also Combo X is a direct rip of the Watcher cards I mentioned and fit her theme very directly
so sash whip could be written as "Combo Attack"?
yeah

I think of it as a general keyword, that may or may not be introduced on Champ, currently it will be just something to use so I can keep majority of current cards, but there is a lot of potential for other characters in it.
also this should be taken as a grain of salt, since i do not enjoy champ or watcher, but those watcher cards weren't fun to me
instead of card order enabling cool things, they were requirements to get their assigned value out of them
without those requirements met they were just strikes with +1/2 damage
i'd rather have card order that rewards the player for naturally using other mechanics rather than be forced

Yeah, I would probably end up converting majority of cards to interact with Technique, or be useful in a different package outside of it, but at least I want to try how mechanic like that would play.
 That said I might keep a few cards if they will work in context of the card pool.

Here's a crazy idea: eliminate the actual "stances" and replace them with individual cards that say "[blank] Stance". These cards would have a primary effect, but then have the secondary effect "Your next three X [trigger effect]" where X is a type of card (attack, skill, strike, etc)
then you have no official stances like watcher, but you can have like 10-20 individual cards that say they're a "stance"
That is also an possibility, but I think that effects like that work better as orbs or orb-like mechanic.
oh really :watcherthink:

In fact Stances that Champ currently has could make for interesting Orbs.
 Play X cards of specific type to trigger an effect, it is just a great effect to display using UI for Orbs, as well as a nice twist on the mechanic itself.
imagine you had throwbacks to watcher's stances in there
"wrath: your next 3 attacks deal double damage"
"calm: your next 3 cards that cost 2 or more Refund 1"
~~idk that one's harder~~
~~what would divinity be~~
"divinity: after you play 10 cards, your next attack deals triple damage"

~~I have heard that you like Relics, but hate how random they are, so we combined them with Orbs into 1 mechanic that you can access during combat, and pick ones that are useful during current situation.~~

like bag of prep or vajra or smooth stone or, because it's Champ, Akabeko

Normally yes, but not today

So champ does have a handful of cards that scale with how many times you've played them, but it's a very minor subtheme (you don't have anything as exciting as limit break+ or entrench to get back). They do also have a very difficult time with drawing cards, so having some deck manipulation is welcome.  I think the issue with headbutt is largely that it's not a very exciting damage common to be adding to your deck for other reasons. Using up your vigor on a non multi-hit attack (especially when you could use this effect to grab a multi-hit attack for next turn) feels pretty bad. You also just have a vast number of better options for dealing frontloaded damage than this, which makes adding headbutt to your deck feel awkward and unnecesary. I think something like <recover> or <reformation> would make more sense, maybe a card that gives some block, enters defensive stance, and sets a card on top.

**Brace** 3 (4).
Place a card from your discard pile into **Stasis.**
